title: Are famous people’s quotations copyrighted? - Quora

response.answer_text: Legally, anything you say is copyrighted as a creative work, unless… The unless part is complex. In general, it means that the thing you said isn’t creative or way too common. There’s also the problem of “prior art” as someone else could have said the same thing before. For example, answering questions is not creative. It’s just an answer so it isn’t copyrighted. General speech is also hard to get copyrighted as you need to show that is was meant to create something artistic, which is generally hard to do. But people talking in a TV show can be copyrighted, even if the dialog is non-scripted. That’s because making a TV show is a creative process and the makers of the show have copyright on the images and basically whatever is said in the show. But then we have “fair use” which would allow parts of the complete dialog to be quoted in reference to the person who said it or the show from where it was taken. Finally, there’s also the point that people don’t even care about the copyrights they have over what they said. In which case it is still copyrighted but no one is stopping any of the violations. To make it even more complex, speeches given by the Federal Government are immediately part of the Public Domain. So if the POTUS tells a children story that he himself created and tells this to a bunch of kids on a school, with a camera filming it all then the story becomes public domain! But the recording of this story-telling can be copyrighted… State Governments, on the other hand, can decide to retain copyright over their own speeches, though. Thus if a speech is made by a State Official, it might be copyrighted. (Still, you have fair use!) Then there’s this question: Could Michelle Obama Sue Melania Trump Over Plagiarized Speech? The answer to that is “maybe” but the story also tells another part of the whole copyright discussion! You have to show that the copyright violation actually caused you (financial) damages and that’s nearly impossible with any speech. You spoke it and everyone heard it. So, how are you losing profits when everyone repeats what you said? So, practically speeches aren’t copyrighted, even if they legally are… You’re moving into a possible minefield if you start quoting famous people, though. They might try to get some financial compensation for it, as you’re making profit from their quotes and they don’t get a share… That’s financial damage… If it will hold in court? Doubtful, but the legal costs for you might be high enough to go bankrupt if you don’t settle it.

There are two things that govern this: Is something that someone said in passing a “work of art”; andIf it is, when was it said?Something that somebody says in itself, as far as I know, is not a work of art. If it was something said by someone who made the comment less than 70 years ago, and then included that comment in, for example, a book, or inscribed upon a painting or sculpture, or even (as I have seen) a drip mat in a bar, which themselves are works of art, then those works of art, by dint of the fact that they ARE works of art, are governed by copyright laws. Similarly if it comes from a speech which is then published in a book, then the book is governed by copyright law. But to the best of my knowledge and belief what someone says cannot in itself be copyrighted. (I’m sure Marvin Gaye’s estate would disagree). My two favourite quotations, which I have no fear of repeating here are: “Take the first step in faith. You do not have to see the whole staircase. Just take the first step.” - Martin Luther King; and“The human body may remain naked and unclothed and retain its beauty and its splendour.” - Karol Wojtyla … whom you probably know better as Pope John Paul II.

Thanks for the Ask. I am not a lawyer. US Copyright laws, and the international Berne Convention, stipulate that the creative expression must be fixed in form (written down, recorded, something). If there is a record of someone saying something, that counts (probably). It is difficult, however, to determine who might hold those copyrights, and if/when they expire. Generally, most stuff goes public 25–120 years from creation, depending on format, region, and when the creator died. The great things about quotes, though, is that they can be used/presented as “fair use” as educational or parody or transformative work, and they’re easy to cite. If you want to plaster a famous quote on something, all you have to do is say “this person said this” and you’re clear. It does get thorny if you want to attribute a quote from fiction, because that can step on copyright licenses that are more exact and specific… and it could be argued that you’re reproducing (infringing) someone else’s property. Feel free to quote J.K. Rowling’s political statements on a T-shirt, but don’t transcribe any Harry Potter dialogue. A good rule of thumb: If the original copyright owner is making money by using this quote (like all the official Harry Potter merch out there), then you should not try to rip it off. If you share some examples, we can give you better answers. As always, if you have money riding on this, it is worth hiring a lawyer. Good luck!

A quote from a famous person would be considered “intellectual property”, and you cannot legally use quotes in commercial work unless you either have written consent from the quote’s author (even if the quote was only ever spoken and not published in writing), or the quote is in the public domain (which usually means it was either spoken or published before 1923). Artist Emily McDowell wrote a great intro article on this topic: Using Famous Quotes On Products: When Is It OK?. I know it’s a bummer that modern quotes can’t be used on commercial work without permission, but it’s good that you asked! It’s definitely the professional and respectful thing to do. On a side note, it might not hurt to create designs with any quote you like for the sole purpose of sharing via social media and growing your audience (with proper credits to the author, of course)… That way if the quote passes into the public domain while you’re still selling products, you might be able to use it for profit at that point.

Are we talking quotations of their writing or things they said out loud? Are we talking about quotes from movies and TV (quotes from characters) or are we talking about things said live, perhaps on the news? Copyright only protects "creatives works". A "work" is a fixed medium, like a novel or movie. Possibly a written speech. So the "I Have A Dream" speech is copyright protected, a quote from Angelina Jolie from a live broadcast is not.

Any words that have been placed into a fixed format are subject to copyright in the US (and in Berne signatories — 171 countries). But if the words were spoken long enough in the past, the copyright may have expired. In the US, that term is the life of the author/speaker plus 70 years.

According to me, if you are using quotes written by others then it's the case of Copyright.  SO that it is good to have a author's written permission for using their words in your own blog.  You can see Wikipedia:Plagiarism for more information.
